required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Early Intrapleural TPA Instillation Versus Late
clinical_study.official_title: Early Intrapleural TPA Instillation Versus Late

brief_summary.textblock: Chest tubes are used for air or fluid removal from the pleural space. When a chest tube is placed, it can be hard for the fluid to drain.Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) and DNase are given through the chest tube to help with draining the fluid. We are doing this research to see if early addition of tPA-DNase immediately after chest tube placement will help with better fluid draining.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the timing and efficacy of early administration and late administration of t-PA/DNase via thoracostomy (n=60). Patients will be identified from the Intensive Care Unit, Coronary Care Unit, and wards/stepdown units. Prior to chest tube placement, patients will be randomized to one of the two treatment arms (early use of t-PA-DNase verus late use of t-PA-DNase). Route of administration will be via their thoracostomy tube over a period of three days twice daily.

secondary_outcome.description: Volume of fluid drained after each tPA and DNase instillation
Post tPA/DNase administration, the need for other interventions, such as surgery or additional chest tube, will be determined.

arm_group.description: 10mg of t-PA and 5 mg of DNase in a 30 mL solution of water/saline administered via chest tube over three days twice daily 24-48 hours after chest tube placed.
10mg of t-PA and 5 mg of DNase in a 30 mL solution of water/saline administered via chest tube over three days twice daily with initial administration occurring at chest tube placement.

intervention.description: Early addition of tPA and DNase (immediately at chest tube placement) versus later (24-48 hours) after chest tube placement.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients, age 18 years or older
- Patients with an indication for a thoracostomy tube placement for a pleural effusion
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients that require a thoracostomy tube for a pneumothorax
- Pregnant women
- Sensitivity to t-PA, or DNase
- Patients taking carbamazepine or nitroglycerin
- Lung volume reduction surgery on side of pleural effusion
